name: Tenrikyo
description: Explore Tenrikyo's unique perspective on death as returning a borrowed body to God the Parent, leading to rebirth for another attempt at the 'Joyous Life', and the focus on collective spiritual evolution.

lessons.title: Tenrikyo: The Joyous Return
lessons.content: Tenrikyo presents death as the act of returning a 'borrowed body' to God the Parent, who loans human forms for precisely 115 years. Early death is attributed to the accumulation of 'dust' in the mind—negative thoughts and attitudes that corrupt this divine gift. This perspective reframes death not as an end, but as a temporary return and preparation for a new beginning. [cite: 631, 632]

questions.explanation: Tenrikyo presents death as returning a borrowed body to God the Parent. [cite: 631]

questions.question: Early death in Tenrikyo is a random occurrence with no specific cause.
questions.explanation: Early death results from 'dust' accumulating in the mind—negative thoughts and attitudes that corrupt the divine gift. [cite: 632]

lessons.title: Passing Away for Rebirth and Karma
lessons.content: In Tenrikyo, death means 'passing away for rebirth'—the soul returns to God's embrace, awaiting a new body. This is not an escape, but a preparation for another attempt at living the 'Joyous Life,' where humanity lives in harmony as God intended. While karma operates, it is tempered by God's parental love and compassion. Suffering is seen as guidance toward spiritual maturity, rather than a punitive punishment. Even tragic deaths are believed to contain lessons for spiritual growth. [cite: 633, 634, 635, 636]

questions.correctAnswer: To prepare for another attempt at the 'Joyous Life'
questions.explanation: Death means 'passing away for rebirth'—the soul returns to God's embrace, waiting for a new body. This isn't escape but preparation for another attempt at the 'Joyous Life'. [cite: 633, 634]

questions.question: In Tenrikyo, suffering is seen as solely a punishment for bad deeds.
questions.explanation: Suffering serves as guidance toward spiritual maturity, not punishment. [cite: 635]

lessons.title: Collective Spiritual Evolution
lessons.content: The ultimate goal in Tenrikyo transcends individual afterlife concerns. The faith aims to transform this world into the divine kingdom through collective spiritual evolution. Personal salvation is considered secondary, or even meaningless, without universal salvation; all humanity must achieve the Joyous Life together. This emphasizes a shared destiny and a communal effort towards a perfected world. [cite: 637, 638]
